In mirrorless cameras the autofocus sensors and the auto exposure sensors are intergraded inside the digital image sensor. This is a compromise and isn't something new. Compact cameras are doing that since the birth of consumer digital cameras. The mirrorless cameras simply have by far better sensors than compact cameras and are equal in quality, speed to nearly all dSLRs. 
The dSLRs have dedicated sensors and that give them an advantage. The auto focus sensors of dSLRs are below the mirror  and the auto exposure sensor near the pentaprism. 
The top models and more expensive models of dSLR cameras have still better autofocus and auto exposure. The big expensive dSLR cameras don't have the compromise of size and weight and that helps the quality of dedicated electronics. 
On the other hand the modern electronics of mirrorless cameras are so advanced that a common photographer won't realize the difference. 
The mirrorless cameras is the future. However Canon, Nikon DSLRs cameras have the huge advantage of their lenses.  Sony, Olympus, Fujifilm etc offer only the basic number of lenses at an equal size and weight of dSLR's lenses. So in the aspect of lenses the mirrorless cameras are inferior. 
The big players Nikon Canon will survive due to theirs  lenses. Lenses are very hard to be made and are not under Moore's law like electronics. A really sharp and bright lens model can be profitable for at least a decade. Anything electronic is loosing its value after three years. 
Sony the last two years brought a decent variety of  full frame e-mount lenses for its mirrorless cameras. Sony nowadays is focused on full frame lenses and have neglected a little  the crop size APS-C e-mount lenses. Sony's full frame lenses for e-mount mirrorless cameras are more expensive and are equally heavy and big as they dSLR equivalent lenses. 
So we haven't seen any revolution in lenses yet. The major third party lens makers Sigma, Tamron offer some lenses for mirrorless cameras but their best lens models are made for dSLR cameras. 
Something that is not pointed as it should, is that Sony has great focus peaking, focus magnifier and internal image stabilization. Focus peaking and focus magnifier make manual focus much faster and easier than with dSLR camera. 
Sony and other manufacturers of mirrorless cameras have opened the road for the forgotten market of no electronic manual focus lenses. 
These lenses were neglected for decades. They were equally sharp at a much lower price. But most photographers were avoiding them because it was harder, slower to focus and the lack of internal image stabilization was increasing ISO. 
Now with mirrorless technology many previously unknown Chinese and Korean companies like Laowa, Rokinon, Zhongyi Mitagon have emerged. They don't have the knowledge of sophisticated autofocus and image stabilization electronics. Nevertheless they can produce smaller very sharp with big aperture lenses at a fraction of price. 
This is the unknown revolution of mirrorless cameras.
